title: Catalyst Proposals Assessment Guide
description: 約89％が「Catalyst to Vote」の提案を評価できませんでした。

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of a assesment guide may be good but the proposal lacks precision. I would like to know in what format the guide will be. A guide can be in forms of youtube videos, blogs and more. I suggest that the proposer refine his proposal to add more precision.
f6_assessments.q1: Due to the lack of precision, I can't see the project being implemented. The proposer wants to build a an assesment guide he doesn't specify the the kind of guide. I hope that proposer can add more precisions on the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has not provided enough informations to audit the progress of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
1. overlap with a proposal

https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/2Min-Review/370212-48088

2. the aim is to increase the number of CA but the survey is performed (as far as I understood) on a sample of Vietnamese community + in the text, the proposer also added, that the assessment will improve 

- how to evaluate
- how to vote

are we sure, that such assessment will increase the number both of CA and voters? I am not sure, if the number of voters is low, because people do not speak the language, or it is because they do not care. If we had more data we could assume better. I understand that it is hard to collect, I am just trying to say, that the proposal might not be AS EFFECTIVE as expected. 

to put it simply:

It will increase the number of voters and CA, but what if it will be only 1%? (if you consider 1% as a success, please take it as a low outcome:))

3. is not 200 people low expectation? - for new voters? If you had 200 CAs, sure, but voters? efficiency seems to be low IMO.
f6_assessments.q1: I am convinced they can deliver - links provided, budget is real for 6 months.
f6_assessments.q2:
metrics provided:

 Completing the " Catalyst Proposal Assessment Guide " : 2021/10/E

- Number of people using the " Catalyst Proposal Assessment Guide " to Vote for Fund8: at least 200 people.

is not 200 people low expectation? - for new voters?

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal does address the challenge quite well. It's great that they back up their assessment of the problem with real info from the Cardano Vietnam community survey; and their aim to "help the community to evaluate proposals by themselves", rather than telling people what to vote for, shows a good grasp of a key principle of distributed decisionmaking.

But – they're basically trying to insert a second  tier of assessment, with separate criteria, in between the proposer and the voter, without explaining how they will communicate these additional criteria to proposers. In order to be transparent (and transparency is a cornerstone of distributed decision making), it'll be important to make sure proposers are aware of these new criteria that they're going to be assessed on; this will take time and effort that's not accounted for here. For example – writing guidance notes? Integrating it all with the challenge settings on Ideascale for fund 8? etc. I'd like to see some awareness in the proposal that this needs to be done by *someone* (even if their plan is for someone else to do it), because not recognising that it needs to be done at all is a bit of a red flag for me as it's so anti-transparent.

I get that the team is using an iterative process to develop the evaluation criteria, and that's great; but I would like to see a little more info, even if it's quite vague, about what kinds of additional criteria they think they might develop in their first iteration, and how these will address the challenge. Or if they really don't have any idea of what the criteria might be until they start working on it, then I'd like some more detail on what their processes will be to develop the first iteration. Will they use any research or consultation to come up with these additional evaluation criteria? How will they ensure that these additional criteria address the challenge and improve distributed decisionmaking, rather than being arbitrary or irrelevant?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal team seem to be quite connected to the Cardano community, which is great, but the information and links given about each of them are a bit opaque, honestly. For example, it's hard to assess from a github with no public repositories , whether someone has the skills to deliver a project, so maybe a little more info on people's skills and experience would be useful. The budget is clear and well broken down, though; and the plan, dates and milestones seem solid and achievable.
f6_assessments.q2: It's good that they are taking an iterative approach, so we can audit progress by looking at e.g. their community survey halfway through and the feedback they get from their testers. Ideally, though, I'd like to see a couple more audit metrics being used. For instance - we can audit whether the target 200 people are using the guide; but can we audit how many of those people actually do go on to vote? And on the qualitative side - as it stands, we can audit "has an assessment guide been made, and are 200 people using it?" What's missing is "...and what do those 200 people think of it? Is it helping?" I'm sure that info will be in the community survey the team plan to do, so it'd be great if they could make explicit how they will collate that info, anonymise it if necessary, and make it available to the community so we can assess what effect this work has had.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is very interesting, because as the authors of the proposal say, less than 10% of the holders of ada participate in the voting process of the Catalyst Project proposals, often because they do not understand the process. I say from experience that I can only perform this work actively because I have a family member who instructed me on how to carry out the assessments. He explained to me how to read the proposals, which criteria to evaluate and etc, and from there I started to study about the fundamental concepts of our ecosystem, such as blockchain, NFT and so on. But people who do not have someone already "in" this universe would certainly have a much harder time understanding how Catalyst works, let alone the act of evaluating proposals! So I thought this was an amazing idea, I would like to have access to the reviews guide myself. This project will certainly contribute a lot to distributed decision making as more people will understand, evaluate and participate in the launch of proposals on Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q1: Regarding the team's ability to execute the proposal, it is very clear how they are technically prepared to do so. The names and professional roles of each author are presented, as well as linkedin profiles attached, in which we can analyze in more detail the professional trajectory of each. We are also provided with a link to a website they created, where we can learn a little more about who they are and their abilities. Thus, in this regard, the proposal is very well situated.
f6_assessments.q2: On the step-by-step of how the project would happen, the authors of the proposal tell us which small steps would make up the whole that would be the "Catalyst Proposal Evaluation Guide". They also measure steps based on months, and establish metrics to measure the proposal's success. About the division of the requested funding, despite providing us with some information, it is not very detailed... for example: human hours. Who would be working, what would people's work routine be like (how many hours a day, for example), which professionals would be involved in each phase? Regarding marketing, we are not specified what kind of advertising campaign they intend to launch, where exactly would the existence of this guide reach the community? Due to these issues, I believe that the details about the execution of the project are good, but it could still improve in some ways.

experience: チーム：マーケティングスペシャリスト、コミュニティアウトリーチ、プロジェクトマネジメント、DevOps、テクニカルコンテンツライター＆アナリスト、英語＆ベトナム語堪能
